title: I don't know the concept of math in ‘SAT’. How can I be good at this? - Quora

response.answer_text: To start off, it is important to note that all questions in the Math section carry the same marks. As a result, doing a harder question will not earn more marks than doing an easy one. The questions get harder as you progress through each section. There's a 25-minute non-calculator section, and a 55-minute calculator section following this. Both sections have questions where there are no multiple choice answers; you must fill out the answers yourself. When practicing SAT Maths, it's important to time yourself. This will improve your stamina for the real exam. Try to do a practice paper every month - you're bound to see improved results and accustom yourself to the format of the exam. Never jump through your wrong answers; always inspect your working and understand where you went wrong in every wrong answer. If you still don't understand a question, ask your Mathematics teacher to help you out. If you have the privilege, I suggest you purchase an SAT Math Practice Guide with sample answers. I recommend you'd buy a specialised one only for SAT Math.

Get yourself a good SAT review book; both Princeton Review and Kaplan make them and you can get them via Amazon books. You can also sign up for a free SAT review vis Khan Academy; they go through all the math you need.
